Primary assembly

Assembled chromosomes for hg38 are chromosomes 1–22 (chr1–chr22), X (chrX), Y (chrY) and Mitochondrial (chrM).
Unlocalized sequences (known to belong on a specific chromosome but with unknown order or orientation) are identified by the _random suffix.
Unplaced sequences (chromosome of origin unknown) are identified by the chrU_ prefix.

GRCh38 ALT contigs, decoy contig
In genomics, a genome reference is a collection of genetic sequences that represents the consensus sequence of a species or a population. However, due to the complexity of many genomes, it is often necessary to include additional sequences in the reference to improve its accuracy or completeness. Two types of additional sequences commonly included in genome references are ALT contigs and decoy contigs.
ALT contigs, also known as alternative contigs, are additional contigs that represent alternative versions of genomic regions that are highly variable or difficult to assemble. These regions may include centromeres, telomeres, or segmental duplications. ALT contigs are typically labeled with an identifier that distinguishes them from the primary reference contigs, which are usually labeled with sequential numbers or letters.
Decoy contigs, on the other hand, are artificial sequences that are added to the reference to represent regions that are likely to be mistaken for real genomic regions during the sequencing or mapping process. These regions may include repetitive elements, transposable elements, or microbial contaminants. Decoy contigs are typically designed to be similar in length and complexity to real genomic regions, but with unique sequence content that can be used to distinguish them from real genomic regions.
The inclusion of ALT contigs and decoy contigs in genome references can help improve the accuracy and completeness of genomic analyses, such as variant calling and read mapping, by reducing the number of false positives and false negatives.
Scaffolds?

Placed scaffolds: the scaffolds have been placed within a chromosome.
Unlocalized scaffolds: although the chromosome within which the scaffold occurs is known, the scaffold’s position or orientation is not known.
Unplaced scaffolds: it is not known which chromosome the scaffold belongs to.

what is the masked and soft-masked sequence types?

‘dna’ - unmasked genomic DNA sequences.
‘dna_rm’ - masked genomic DNA. Interspersed repeats and low complexity regions are detected with the RepeatMasker tool and masked by replacing repeats with ’N’s.
‘dna_sm’ - soft-masked genomic DNA. All repeats and low complexity regions have been replaced with lowercased versions of their nucleic base

title: NCBI
text:
2.3 E-utilities

Nine E-utilities

EInfo –> database statistics
ESearch –> text search
EPost –> UID uploads
ESummary –> document summary downloads
EFetch –> data record downloads
ELink –> Entrez links
-related: Neighbors in same database
-target: Links in different database
-cited: reference to this parer(pubmed)
-cites: publication reference list
-cmd: history,neighbor,acheck
EGQuery –> global query
ESpell –> spelling suggestions
EciMatch –> batch citation searching in PubMed

pipeline

Retrieving data records matching an Entrez query

ESearch -> Esummary
Esearch - > EFetch

Retrieving data records matching a list of UIDs

Esearch -> ELink
EPost -> ELink

Finding UIDs linked to a set of records

EPost -> ESearch
ELikn -> ESearch

Limiting a set of records with an Entrez query

ESearch -> ELink -> ESummary
ESearch -> ELink -> EFetch

Retrieving data records in database B linked to records in database A matching an Entrez query

EPost -> ESearch -> ESummary
EPOst -> ESearch -> EFetch

Retrieving data records from a subset of an ID list defined by an Entrez query

EPost -> ESearch -> ESummary
EPost -> ESearch -> EFetch

Retrieving a set of data records, defined by an Entrez query, in database B from a larger set of records linked to a list of UIDs in database A

EPost -> ELink -> ESearch -> ESummary
EPost -> ELink -> ESearch -> EFetch


Entrez Direct: E-utilities on the Unix Command Line

How to add keys
export NCBI_API_KEY=unique_api_key
resources

Entrez Unique Identifiers (UIDs) for selected databases

example

search pubmed
# 1) examples context "NLRP3 AND TCGA"
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" | esummary

# 2) search with date options
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2022 -maxdate 2023

# 3) sort by revelence or title or pub datetype
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
efetch -format xml

# 4) search pubmed, fetch the format, and extract the authors,your could use `-sep` to seprate element,or `-tab` to sperate block
esearch -db pubmed -query "selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor" |
efetch -format xml |
xtract -pattern PubmedArticle -block Author -element LastName, Initials

# 5) search pubmed with text, return the medline format
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" | efetch -format medline

# 6) search pubmed with text and extract the 1) journal 2) title  3) abastrct 4) author 5) keyword
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
efetch -format xml |
xtract -pattern PubmedArticle \
-block Journal  -element "Title" \
-block Article -element "ArticleTitle" \
-block Author -sep " " -tab ", " -element Initials,LastName \
-block KeywordList -sep "," -element "Keyword" \
-block Abstract -element "AbstractText"

# 7) search pubmed text, and get the related results
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
elink -related | 
efetch -xml

# 8) search pubmed text, and get the related paper
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
elink -target pubmed 

# 9) search pubmed text, and get the related genes/protein...
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
elink -target gene 

esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
elink -target protein 
search gene
# 1) search gene in Y in homo sampiens, use other programming tools to find the gene in forward or reverse strand
esearch -db gene -query  "Homo sapiens [ORGN] AND Y [CHR]" |
efilter -query "alive [PROP]" |
esummary |
xtract -pattern DocumentSummary -NAME Name \
-block GenomicInfoType -match "ChrLoc:Y" \
-element "&NAME", ChrLoc, ChrAccVer, ChrStart, ChrStop

# 2) search a gene get its  transcript
esearch -db gene -query "TP53[gene name] AND Homo sapiens[ORGN]"|
efetch -format fasta
search proteins
search proteins for each genes using elink
esearch -db gene -query "NLPR3 AND Homo sapiens [ORGN] AND alive [prop]"|
elink -target protein -name gene_protein_refseq -cmd neighbor | 
xtract -pattern LinkSet -block IdList -element Id -block LinkSetDb -element Id
xtract tips

pattern  with capitals, create a variable , invoke it with &STRINGS
A slash (/) to indicate Parent/Child construction
esearch -db pubmed -query "NLRP3 AND TCGA" -datetype PDAT -mindate 2021 -maxdate 2023 -sort "Pub Date" |
efetch -format xml |
xtract -pattern PubmedArticle -element PubDate/Year

Others

alive[prop]: currently alive

title: TCGA
text:
Data_Transfer_Tool

download the manifest
download with gdc-client (redo with split manifest)
#!/bin/bash
usage ()
{
echo 'Usage : command <manifest.file> <cores>'
exit
}

if [ $# != 2 ];then
usage
fi 
# 1) parrelle using xargs; 2) download with gdc-client
wc -l $1 >> logs.txt
tail -n +2 $1 | \
cut -f1 |\
xargs -n 1 -P $2 \
/home/keke/app/conda/envs/tcga/bin/gdc-client download &
wait
# 3) calculate time
end=`date +%s`
runtime=$((end-start))
echo ">>>Running Finished...." >> logs.txt
echo ">>>Running times is ...." >> logs.txt
echo $runtime >>logs.txt

title: single cell
text:
Guidelines for annotate single cell?
https://sci-hub.mksa.top/10.1038/s41596-021-00534-0
three steps
 1. annotate use predefined set of marker genes

     * marker based tools

     * reference based tools

 2.  manual annotation

     * lower confidence, conflicting or absent cell labels, expert manual annotation is required

     * 

 3. verification(1. other methods, 2. new validation experiments)

     * statistical methods

     * expert

your should prepare

csl file: download from github

bib: you could prepare using endnote
bib file example
@article{knuth:1984,
  title={Literate Programming},
  author={Donald E. Knuth},
  journal={The Computer Journal},
  volume={27},
  number={2},
  pages={97--111},
  year={1984},
  publisher={Oxford University Press}
}
